We explore the impact of an initial transformation using Fourier transform \\( \\mathcal{F}(u)(\\xi) = \\int_{\\mathbb{R}^n} e^{-2 \\pi i x \\cdot \\xi} u(x, 0) \\, dx \\) and study the system evolution.

Given the temperature distribution \\( u(x, T) \\), can we unambiguously determine if any changes in diffusivity constants (from \\( \\kappa \\) to \\( \\kappa' \\)) occurred at some time \\( t_1 \\) during the evolution, just by knowing \\( u(x, T) \\)?
Explanation: The presence of different diffusion rates at different times can create similar effects to varying initial conditions or external heat sources/sinks, making it difficult to precisely attribute the observed final state to specific changes in thermal properties without additional data.
